body:
Since we are using hybrid style and the Google C++ style guide does not make the case for requiring braces, I would like to ask for an explicit ruling on whether neovim code should require braces always. Lack of braces is known to be the cause of many unnecessary and damaging bugs:
- https://www.imperialviolet.org/2014/02/22/applebug.html
- http://www.tedunangst.com/flak/post/a-brief-history-of-one-line-fixes

comment_data.body: Agreed. I will add that explicitly in #192

I've heard this _so_ many times, and I can still not remember ever having a single bug due to not using braces for single statements. We all make different kind of bugs, but is it really that common - you see even the Google guide that's trying to avoid bugs doesn't require it?

I agree that you should use braces if one of the if's needs braces.

Yes, it is that common. And it gets worse if often do if..else. +1 on
making braces mandatory.

On Mon, Mar 3, 2014 at 9:25 PM, simendsjo notifications@github.com wrote:

> I've heard this _so_ many times, and I can still not remember ever having
> a single bug due to not using braces for single statements. We all make
> different kind of bugs, but is it really that common - you see even the
> Google guide that's trying to avoid bugs doesn't require it?
> 
> I agree that you should use braces if one of the if's needs braces.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/266#issuecomment-36555102
> .

## 

Mikael Jansson
http://mikael.jansson.be

@simendsjo This very problem made headlines recently.  Apple's gotofail SSL bug was a repeated line, but the if didn't have braces.  So the second copy got on the main path and [circumvented some protections](http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2014/02/gotofail/).  I'm not saying braces would have solved the problem, but I bet it would have helped someone notice the issue.

> I bet it would have helped someone notice the issue.

Maybe. Enabling -Wunreachable-code would have shown the bug instantly. Running a static analyzer would have shown the bug instantly.

I think discussing what did happen, what could have happened, and what has happened to anyone else is mostly unfruitful. There are two prevailing opinions and they will never be aligned, however, it is an undeniable fact that _requiring_ braces _completely eliminates_ an entire class of potential bugs. Whether or not anyone has ever experienced such bugs is significantly less relevant.

I was actually under the impression it had been decided to go with

``` C
if (foo) bar(); // Optional braces.
if (foo) { // Mandatory braces.
  bar();
}
```

Mandatory braces enforces the "blank" line. :D
On Mar 3, 2014 5:53 PM, "simendsjo" notifications@github.com wrote:

> When we're talking about a source of bugs with if statements, I think this
> is worse (and I've seen it several places in the codebase):
> 
> if (a)
>   do_something();
> if (b)
>   do_something_else();
> else
>   do_another();
> 
> The problem here is a missing blank line after the first if. It easily
> looks like if (b) is an else if (b)
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/266#issuecomment-36558254
> .
:+1: for mandatory braces; based on the title I was going to link that apple bug too.
:+1: for mandatory braces everywhere; golang got this right.

@simendsjo 

> I've heard this so many times, and I can still not remember ever having a single bug due to not using braces for single statements

I have to disagree, the [`goto fail`](https://gist.github.com/davepeck/9151493#file-oops-c-L58) bug was in the media just a couple of days ago.

Therefore :+1: for mandatory braces everywhere.

We can find examples of a single source of error having fatal consequences if we just look.
This concrete example has great ramifications, but it still mostly shows some extremely sloppy code-review rather than a broken coding-style.

I'm pretty sure not using yoda-expressions is a greater source of errors and harder to spot under review than this issue - which is legal in many style-guides.

And I think it's much, much worse using a type that supports `2^32` values when only `2` of them are legal. And having variables as `char*` when an `enum` would be better etc etc.

I don't think we should try to mold the coding style such that it tries to catch every possible type of bug because that obviously be an exercise in futility; however, I think that enforcing mandatory braces would not cause any particular hindrance because 1) we can easily fill in the missing braces in an initial code cleanup using `uncrustify` and my `uncrustify.cfg` and 2) a good number of us habitually add braces around expressions anyway.

I think we should just add this rule and then call this coding convention discussion finalized for now so that we can start actually making neovim great. Does that sound like a plan?
Concur.
Disagree, but majority rules.

+1 for braces always.
I agree with @scott-linder, go solved all this "style" issues in a very neat way IMHO.
I don't have a problem with a more consistent coding style so +1 for mandatory braces.

How about a compromise? We will use braces everywhere in new code but don't change old code (unless we refactor it anyways).

@simendsjo about terniary expression: I agree that they are error thrown but only if used for complex computations especially nested ones. Simple expressions like `x = y > 0 ? y : -y` are simple enough to justify not using an if/else construct.
+1 mandatory braces please
+1 from me too
@davidzchen if this rule was already added to clint/uncrustify I will close this issue

@tarruda This rule has already been added to uncrustify, which now automatically adds the missing braces, and I believe @mahkoh is adding this rule to his clint/styleguide rework in #302. Feel free to close this issue.
Ok, thanks

title: require braces after if/while/... blocks, even one-liners
